refined_goal: Build an ultra-autonomous discovery engine that scouts the open internet and code ecosystems using only lightweight embeddings and protocol-native signals—no heavyweight ML stack—then curates and explains its finds through a self-adaptive dashboard. Concretely: a Spring Boot 3 service orchestrates discovery “micro-policies,” uses Retrofit2 as a dynamic protocol layer to explore APIs and web endpoints, and computes compact 128–256D int8 hash-based embeddings (SimHash + SRP + token sketches) for near-duplicate detection, novelty ranking, and relevance search. Success criteria: sub-50 ms per-item embedding; >85% duplicate collapse on long-tail sources; <5% API rate-limit violations; time-to-signal (finding a novel, high-health repo) under 10 minutes from a cold start; operator UI latency <150 ms on 10k items. Why it matters: it proves that meaningful autonomous discovery doesn’t require GPUs—only clever encoding, typed HTTP, and a composable UI—making exploration cheap, explainable, and deployable anywhere.
repository_synergy:
THE INSIGHT: Retrofit’s annotation-driven HTTP layer isn’t just for mobile clients—it’s a portable schema-on-call engine. If we treat unknown endpoints as dynamic interfaces, Retrofit becomes our “organ of sensing,” while Spring Boot orchestrates autonomous loops that learn where to probe next. Meanwhile, Tabler and AdminLTE are far more than themes: they’re two distinct information architectures we can hot-swap to visualize exploration strategies. The illicit connection is to repurpose Retrofit’s Converter and CallAdapter factories as lightweight embedding and policy adapters, while using Boot’s auto-configuration to wire them in real time. The UI libraries become a living control room for the agent’s brain, not mere cosmetics.

THE STORY: Why these repos, not the obvious semantic stacks? Heavy LLM embeddings are overkill for a scouting system that needs to be frugal, transparent, and deployable in constrained environments. Spring Boot contributes battle-tested lifecycle, scheduling, Actuator metrics, and conditional auto-config that lets us snap in new discovery policies without restarts. Retrofit gives us declarative HTTP contracts, interceptors for caching and rate limiting, and an adapter ecosystem that we can subvert to turn every response into a compact vector sketch. Tabler and AdminLTE offer two mature, different UX grammars: Tabler excels at crisp information density; AdminLTE shines with widgets and ops metaphors. Alternating them isn’t stylistic—it’s cognitive: each skin privileges different signals (trend deltas vs. system health vs. policy tuning), letting humans think better with the machine.

THE SYNERGY: Boot’s configuration graph can scan the classpath for annotated Retrofit interfaces (@Discoverable) and auto-register them with policies. Retrofit’s Converter.Factory, instead of only JSON-to-POJO, can extract tokens from HTML, Markdown, READMEs, and OpenAPI docs, then emit EmbeddableResource payloads. A CallAdapter.Factory can transform Retrofit calls into DiscoveryTasks with backoff, ETag awareness, and semantic delta checks (SimHash unchanged? Skip deep parse). Tabler/AdminLTE, served by Boot, render real-time streaming SSE panels: one skin emphasizes novelty and long-tail clustering; the other surfaces incidents, policy changes, and cache efficiency.

THE INNOVATION: Combining these yields a GPU-free, agentic explorer that balances health, novelty, and relevance at internet scale-on-a-budget. The bridge is illicit because we’re using Retrofit’s type system as a programmable probe language, Boot as an auto-wiring policy engine, and CSS dashboards as cognitive prosthetics for operator-in-the-loop science. That unlocks new behaviors: runtime synthesis of Retrofit interfaces from discovered OpenAPI specs; instant similarity joins via 64–256 bit sketches; and "semantic delta caching" that prevents costly recomputation when content hasn’t meaningfully changed.
technical_architecture:
Core modules in Spring Boot 3:

- Scout Engine: A policy-driven scheduler (virtual threads recommended) that runs discovery loops. Policies define seed endpoints, follow rules, and termination criteria. RateLimiter and BudgetManager guard API quotas.

- Retrofit Layer: Retrofit2 with OkHttp3, configured with:
  - Interceptors: ETag/If-None-Match, conditional GET, user-agent rotation, exponential backoff.
  - Converter.Factory: EmbeddingConverter that parses JSON, HTML, Markdown, YAML; extracts n-gram tokens (3–5), URL shards, code identifiers; applies signed random projection (128–256D int8) and a 64-bit SimHash; emits EmbeddableResource{meta, features, simhash}.
  - CallAdapter.Factory: returns DiscoveryTask objects that carry retry policy, deadlines, and provenance.

- Memory + Index:
  - Lightweight vector store: int8 arrays + 64-bit simhash for prefilter; bitset popcount for quick Hamming checks; optional RoaringBitmap for set ops. LSH buckets (banding) to bound neighbors. Caffeine for response and feature cache.
  - Provenance log (PostgreSQL or embedded RocksDB) tracking fetch times, headers, fingerprints, and links.

- Policy Runtime:
  - Annotated @Discoverable interfaces (e.g., GitHub API, Maven Central, arbitrary site maps). Auto-configuration scans and registers connectors. OpenAPI intake synthesizes Retrofit interfaces at runtime for unknown domains.
  - Scorers: novelty (LSH occupancy), health (stars/issues/release cadence), relevance (keyword sig + link co-mentions). All operate on sketches to keep CPU/ram low.

- UI Delivery and Telemetry:
  - Boot serves two skins: /tabler and /adminlte. SSE streams "ticks" (new resources, cluster merges, cache hits). Tabler view for exploration graphs; AdminLTE for ops & quotas. Boot Actuator exposes metrics and toggles (enable policy, adjust budget) with role-based control.

Performance/optimizations:
- Semantic delta caching: if simhash unchanged within tolerance, skip deep parse and embedding.
- Virtual threads reduce per-call overhead; OkHttp connection pools; GZIP + Brotli support.
- Bloom filters per domain to avoid revisiting URLs.
- Batch neighbor lookups using SIMD-friendly popcount across long[] blocks.

APIs:
- /api/ingest, /api/search (Hamming radius, cosine-on-int8), /api/policies, /api/stream. All JSON over HTTP, SSE for live feeds. Retrofit clients double as internal connectors and external SDK.
expected_impact:
Use cases made concrete:

1) Long-tail OSS radar for CTOs: A policy seeds by topic plus health heuristics, then autonomously surfaces repos with rising velocity but low overlap with existing stack. Embeddings collapse forks and template clones, preventing echo-chamber picks. Result: weekly brief that actually finds unfamiliar, high-signal projects.

2) API drift sentinel: Point at a SaaS vendor’s docs and OpenAPI. The engine fingerprints responses; when simhash shifts beyond threshold, it alerts with a diff of tokens and example failing calls. No heavy NLP required—just structural signal.

3) Incident triage autopilot: During an outage, switch to the AdminLTE skin and enable the "blast radius" policy. The system crawls issues, status pages, mailing lists, producing a deduped stream of actionable links clustered by similarity. Time-to-signal drops from hours to minutes.

4) Compliance inventory scout: Given org domains, the scout lightly probes public registries (Maven, npm) for packages used and discovers transitive risks, correlating with license tokens. Low-cost embeddings prevent redundant processing across similar manifests.

5) Gateway to offline mirrors: In air-gapped environments, feed a static mirror. The engine builds a semantic index usable for on-prem search and dedupe, computed entirely with CPU-friendly hashing.

6) Micro-market research: Aim at community forums and readmes to detect emerging patterns (e.g., surge in vector DB adapters) without training a domain model. Tabler view highlights cluster birth events.

7) Lightweight mobile client: Because connectors are Retrofit-defined, a pared-down Android or JVM client can run focused discovery on-device for niche collections, syncing sketches back to the server.

Limitations and mitigations:
- Shallow semantics: token-based embeddings may miss nuanced meaning. Mitigate with domain lexicons and a small curated keyword bank.
- CSS skin collisions: serve skins separately (/tabler vs /adminlte) and isolate assets.
- Rate limiting: strict budgets and adaptive backoff per connector.
- Cold start bias: seed with diverse vantage points and decay weights to encourage exploration.
innovation_analysis:
Innovation score: 9/10. Repurposing Retrofit’s converter and call adapters as an embedding pipeline and policy substrate, combined with Spring Boot’s auto-configuration and dual-UX skins as cognitive switches, is a non-obvious, elegant route to GPU-free autonomous discovery. It leverages protocol-native signals, streaming UI, and smart caching to deliver real-time usefulness.

Next steps:
- Implement EmbeddingConverterFactory with SRP + SimHash and content-type parsers.
- Build three connectors (GitHub Search, Maven Central, generic HTML) and two seed policies.
- Wire SSE streams to Tabler and AdminLTE pages; add Actuator toggles for budgets.
- Add LSH index with bitset prefilter and Caffeine-backed delta cache.

Key metrics:
- Time-to-signal; duplicate collapse rate; cache hit ratio; API quota efficiency; UI latency; operator intervention count.

Essential tools:
- Java 21 (virtual threads), Spring Boot 3.x, Retrofit2 + OkHttp, Caffeine, RoaringBitmap, PostgreSQL/RocksDB, SSE/WebSocket, Tabler + AdminLTE assets.

sources.name: spring-projects/spring-boot
sources.readme_snippet:
= Spring Boot image:https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/actions/workflows/build-and-deploy-snapshot.yml/badge.svg?branch=main["Build Status", link="https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/actions/workflows/build-and-deploy-snapshot.yml?query=branch%3Amain"] image:https://img.shields.io/badge/Revved%20up%20by-Develocity-06A0CE?logo=Gradle&labelColor=02303A["Revved up by Develocity", link="https://ge.spring.io/scans?&search.rootProjectNames=Spring%20Boot%20Build&search.rootProjectNames=spring-boot-build"]

:docs: https://docs.spring.io/spring-boot
:github: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot

Spring Boot helps you to create Spring-powered, production-grade applications and services with absolute minimum fuss.
It takes an opinionated view of the Spring platform so that new and existing users can quickly get to the bits they need.

You can use Spring Boot to create stand-alone Java applications that can be started using `java -jar` or more traditional WAR deployments.
We also provide a command-line tool that runs Spring scripts.

Our primary goals are:

* Provide a radically faster and widely accessible getting started experience for all Spring development.
* Be opinionated, but get out of the way quickly as requirements start to diverge from the defaults.
* Provide a range of non-functional features common to large classes of projects (for example, embedded servers, security, metrics, health checks, externalized configuration).
* Absolutely no code generation and no requirement for XML configuration.



== Installation and Getting Started

The {docs}[reference documentation] includes detailed {docs}/installing.html[installation instructions] as well as a comprehensive {docs}/tutorial/first-application/index.html[``getting started``] guide.

Here is a quick teaser of a complete Spring Boot application in Java:

[source,java]
----
import org.springframework.boot.*;
import org.springframework.boot.autoconfigure.*;
import org.springframework.we

sources.name: square/retrofit
sources.readme_snippet:
Retrofit
========

A type-safe HTTP client for Android and Java.

For more information please see [the website][1].


Download
--------

Download [the latest JAR][2] or grab from Maven central at the coordinates `com.squareup.retrofit2:retrofit:3.0.0`.

Snapshots of the development version are available in [Sonatype's `snapshots` repository][snap].

Retrofit requires at minimum Java 8+ or Android API 21+.


R8 / ProGuard
-------------

If you are using R8 the shrinking and obfuscation rules are included automatically.

ProGuard users must manually add the options from
[retrofit2.pro][proguard file].
You might also need [rules for OkHttp][okhttp proguard] which is a dependency of this library.


License
=======

    Copyright 2013 Square, Inc.

    Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License");
    you may not use this file except in compliance with the License.
    You may obtain a copy of the License at

       http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0

    Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software
    distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS,
    WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied.
    See the License for the specific language governing permissions and
    limitations under the License.


 [1]: https://square.github.io/retrofit/
 [2]: https://search.maven.org/remote_content?g=com.squareup.retrofit2&a=retrofit&v=LATEST
 [snap]: https://s01.oss.sonatype.org/content/repositories/snapshots/
 [proguard file]: https://github.com/square/retrofit/blob/master/retrofit/src/main/resources/META-INF/proguard/retrofit2.pro
 [okhttp proguard]: https://square.github.io/okhttp/r8_proguard/
 [okio proguard]: https://square.github.io/okio/#r8-proguard

sources.name: ColorlibHQ/AdminLTE
sources.readme_snippet:
# [AdminLTE - Bootstrap 5 Admin Dashboard](https://adminlte.io)

[![npm version](https://img.shields.io/npm/v/admin-lte/latest.svg)](https://www.npmjs.com/package/admin-lte)
[![Packagist](https://img.shields.io/packagist/v/almasaeed2010/adminlte.svg)](https://packagist.org/packages/almasaeed2010/adminlte)
[![cdn version](https://data.jsdelivr.com/v1/package/npm/admin-lte/badge)](https://www.jsdelivr.com/package/npm/admin-lte)
[![Discord Invite](https://img.shields.io/badge/discord-join%20now-green)](https://discord.gg/jfdvjwFqfz)
[![Netlify Status](https://api.netlify.com/api/v1/badges/1277b36b-08f3-43fa-826a-4b4d24614b3c/deploy-status)](https://app.netlify.com/sites/adminlte-v4/deploys)

**AdminLTE** is a fully responsive administration template. Based on **[Bootstrap 5](https://getbootstrap.com/)** framework and also the JavaScript plugins.
Highly customizable and easy to use. Fits many screen resolutions from small mobile devices to large desktops.

## What's New in v4.0.0-rc5

**Latest Release with Major Dependency Updates & Security Fixes** - Fresh improvements for better development experience:

- **Major Dependency Updates** - 17+ npm packages updated to latest versions
- **Security Enhancements** - Fixed 2 critical vulnerabilities (axios DoS, form-data random function)
- **Latest Tooling** - Updated to TypeScript 5.9.3, ESLint 9.37.0, Astro 5.14.4, and more
- **Bootstrap 5.3.8** - Updated to the latest stable Bootstrap release
- **ESLint 9.x Compatibility** - Removed deprecated `.eslintignore` file
- **Zero Vulnerabilities** - All security issues resolved

**Key Improvements:**
- ✅ All dependencies updated to their absolute latest versions
- ✅ Two major version bumps: cross-env 10.x and eslint-config-xo-typescript 9.x
- ✅ Enhanced security with vulnerability fixes
- ✅ Cleaner linting without deprecation warnings
- ✅ Production-ready with enhanced stability
- ✅ Faster builds with latest Rollup, Sass, and Terser

**Install the latest:**
```bash
npm install adm

blueprint.summary: Recombination of recent GitHub innovations with long-tail exploration, health/reputation signals, and optional semantic relevance.
why_it_works: Novelty + Health + Author signals + Semantic relevance elevate hidden gems.

Permissive licensing keeps integration safe and fast.
